labels.text: In his practice, Hans Tan obliquely reinterprets and draws from vernacular archetypes found in Singapore by tinkering with contemporary design morphology and manufacturing processes. In the Spotted Nyonya series, tradition is reinvented not through addition or mimicry, but through subtraction. Tan masks historic Malay-Chinese Peranakan ceremonial ware with a dotted motif made of vinyl stickers, and then sandblasts the vessels. The stickers protect the image underneath, and the vessels are adorned with bold new geometric patterns when the process is complete. Pour, on the other hand, resulted from Tan’s questioning of the resin-casting method by seeking to ‘mould without a mould’. He was inspired by the preparation of kueh lapis sagu—a traditional steamed pastry—and cast a table surface upside down, without walls to hold the liquid resin in. The samples demonstrate Tan’s system of using an epoxy resin that is viscous and that quickly hardens, producing a surface strong enough to function as a table top. Each colour is poured with precise control of curing time to avoid mixing, to achieve a seamless multi-coloured surface.

陳彥翰的創作常從當代設計的外觀形態研究和製 造過程入手，間接從新加坡民間的風格原貌獲得 靈感，並將之重新演繹。在 《點點娘惹》 系 列中，他透過刪減而非增補或模仿的方法重現傳 統。陳彥翰在馬來土生華人的娘惹瓷器上，貼上 圓點貼紙，然後噴砂加工。釉彩受到貼紙保護， 令加工後瓷器上新的幾何圖樣鮮明可見。  另一方面，陳彥翰質疑傳統樹脂的澆鑄方式。 
在《 倒》一 作中，他嘗試不用模具鑄模。受傳統蒸 製點心娘惹九層糕的準備工序啟發，陳彥翰澆鑄 的桌子上下倒置，澆注液態樹脂時亦不用模具定 型。樣品展示了陳彥翰如何使用一種黏稠的人工 樹脂，快速凝固後表面堅硬，可作桌面之用。此 外，在傾注每一種顏色的樹脂時，須精準地控制 凝固時間，以免混合其他顏色，從而形成一片無 縫的彩色平面。
